options: Counter-sign all of the prescriptions with your own name/signature
Take a full medication history from the patient and prescribe appropriately
Find the doctor who signed the prescriptions and ask them to write their name/signature
Leave the chart for the doctor who initially wrote the prescriptions to deal with
Highlight the need to sign all prescriptions at the next team meeting
questions:
You are an F2 working in general surgery. You see a prescription where the medications have been entered but a name/signature is missing for each prescription. You are informed by the nurse in charge of the ward that the medications won't be dispensed if there is no signature next to the prescriptions.

Rank in order the following actions in response to this situation
(1 = Most appropriate; 5 = Least appropriate)
notes:
GMC guidelines state:

'16. In providing clinical care you must:
...prescribe drugs or treatment, including repeat prescriptions, only when you have adequate knowledge of the patient's health and are satisfied that the drugs or treatment serve the patient's needs.'

Based on this, asking the doctor who initially wrote the prescription to sign it is most appropriate (C).

Whilst taking a full medication history is also correct, it is far more time-consuming to do this (B).

Highlight the need to sign all prescriptions at the next team meeting (E) is a useful course of action but it does not deal with the immediate situation. A patient not receiving the correct medication could represent an imminent risk to their health.

Leaving the chart for the doctor who wrote the prescriptions initially is not appropriate (D) as it does nothing to help remedy the situation. However, it is better than counter-signing the prescriptions (A) without any prior knowledge about the patient. This is not appropriate as you do not know whether these prescriptions are correctly serving the patient's needs. It may potentially be dangerous and is hence ranked last.

options: Raise your concerns with your FY2 colleague
Report your colleague to the GMC
Discuss your colleague's behaviour with other FY2s
Speak to the consultant in charge about the issue
Tell your FY2 colleague that their behaviour is unprofessional
questions:
You are a Foundation Year 2 doctor working on a busy general medical ward. You have noticed that your FY2 colleague is frequently coming in late and working less compared to you.

Rank in order the appropriateness of the following actions in response to this situation (1= Most appropriate; 5= Least appropriate).
notes: This question focuses on the importance of professionalism, managing your workload and maintaining patient safety. In this scenario, the most appropriate initial action would be to raise your concerns with your FY2 colleague (A) - it may be that they have some personal circumstances that have been affecting their punctuality and performance issues. It is also best to try and resolve matters internally by discussing your concerns with your colleagues. The next most appropriate option would be to involve the consultant in charge of the issue (D) - they may not be aware of the situation and should be notified if there are any problems concerning managing workload. They may be able to investigate the issue concerning your FY2 colleague but also help provide you with additional support if jobs cannot be completed in a timely manner. Telling your FY2 colleague that their behaviour is unprofessional (E) is not appropriate. Although it may highlight to them that their punctuality is having a significant impact on your workload, it would be more appropriate to discuss your concerns with a less confrontational approach. Discussing your colleague's behaviour with other FY2s (C) is unprofessional - it may be that your colleague is experiencing personal issues, and discussing their behaviour at work could be seen as a breach of their confidentiality. However, the least appropriate option would be to refer your colleague to the GMC (B) - this is completely premature and unwarranted at this stage.

title: GMC: Good medical practice - Communication, partnership and teamwork
body:
Communication, partnership and teamwork form one of the four domains listed in the Good Medical Practice. This domain focuses on the standards expected of doctors in areas such as communication and collaboration with patients and colleagues.

Effective communication
  • Listen to patients and answer any questions honestly
  • Ensure that information is delivered in a manner that can be understood. Identify and apply practical measures to overcome any communication and language barriers
  • Provide support and information to patients' relatives or carers in a considerate manner
  • Doctors on duty need to be easily reachable by their patients and colleagues for any advice or support

Partnership with patients
  • Empower patients with the information required for patients to make decisions with regards to their care. This includes information on the clinical conditions, treatment options and the relevant risks and uncertainties
  • Ensure that patients are aware of the progress of their care
  • The roles and responsibilities of each member of the team need to be made clear to the patients
  • Patient confidentiality needs to be maintained, even after the patient is deceased

Fair and respectful care of all patients
  • Respect patients' dignity and privacy
  • Respect any health, cultural and religious beliefs held by the patients, even if they do not agree with yours.

If you have a conscientious objection to a particular procedure e.g. abortion, you need to:
  • Inform the patient that they have the right to see another practitioner
  • Provide the necessary information and support towards the patient seeking another doctor. In doing so, refrain from expressing disapproval of the patient's lifestyle, choices or beliefs
  • Find another doctor to substitute you if it is not practical for the patient to arrange to see another doctor

Partnership with colleagues
  • Doctors are expected to work in a team in a manner that serves patients' best interest
  • It is important to respect the skills and contributions of every member of the team and be fair to every member of the team
  • Understand that your actions may affect others within and outside the team
  • It is your duty to complete any post that you have formally accepted as leaving the post assigned to you may compromise patient safety especially if this creates a gap in the medical rota
  • Unless the trust has a reasonable time to make adjustments, it is important that you work the hours required of your contract before leaving a job

Coordination of care between healthcare providers and between health and social care providers. This include
  • Providing all relevant information to all clinicians or social care providers involved in the care of the patients
  • Checking that a named doctor or team has taken over the care
  • Ensure that the clinician filling in for you or taking over the care is appropriately trained to provide safe care for the patient

The Good Medical Practice also made statements with regards to Doctors as teachers. It recommends that doctors support the training and teaching of junior staff members and medical students*. This includes
  • Ensuring adequate supervision
  • Writing honest feedback/references/appraisals on their competence, performance and conduct
  • Being a mentor
  • Supporting those who are struggling with their performance or health

*In all circumstances, patient safety needs to be prioritised

options: Breach confidentiality in the interests of the general public
Do nothing
Inform your consultant
Decline to comment on the patient you have seen
Explain that you cannot breach patient confidentiality
Obtain consent from the patient
Ask the patient if he has been involved in a bar fight
Tell the officer you have seen a patient matching the description
questions:
You are a junior doctor working in the Emergency Department. You see a patient with numerous superficial cuts and bruises, who tells you that he fell off his push bike. You suspect that he might be lying to you as the injuries do not fit the story but treat him regardless. A short while later a police officer arrives enquiring about a man who had been in a bar fight the previous evening. He tells you that the other man had suffered from no major injuries but was looking to press charges. You suspect that the man you had treated earlier in the day could have been involved. What do you do?

Select the THREE most appropriate actions to take in this situation
notes:
From the information given in the scenario, it would be safe to assume that the risk of breaching patient confidentiality is greater than the risk to the general public. Hence the best options would be to decline to comment and explain to the officer that you cannot breach confidentiality. Informing your consultant is also a very sensible option. They can offer advice and support your decision.

By telling the officer you have seen a patient matching the description you are beginning to breach confidentiality. Calling security in this situation is not only likely to breach confidentiality, it is also an extreme measure given that the patient poses no immediate threat to you or others from the information given. Confidentiality issue aside, the patient has not disclosed that he was involved in a fight. Therefore to pass on what is nothing more than a suspicion on your part could be a very dangerous move.

title: General Medical Council: duties of a doctor
body:
Make the care of your patient your first concern

Protect and promote the health of patients and the public
  • Provide a good standard of practice and care
  • Keep your professional knowledge and skills up to date
  • Recognise and work within the limits of your competence
  • Work with colleagues in the ways that best serve patients' interests

Treat patients as individuals and respect their dignity
  • Treat patients politely and considerately
  • Respect patients' right to confidentiality

Work in partnership with patients
  • Listen to patients and respond to their concerns and preferences
  • Give patients the information they want or need in a way they can understand
  • Respect patients' right to reach decisions with you about their treatment and care
  • Support patients in caring for themselves to improve and maintain their health

Be honest and open and act with integrity
  • Act without delay if you have good reason to believe that you or a colleague may be putting patients at risk
  • Never discriminate unfairly against patients or colleagues
  • Never abuse your patients' trust in you or the public's trust in the profession.
concept: The only time it is reasonable to break patient confidentiality is when there is a greater risk to the general public

options: Explain that once the consent form is signed there is nothing that can be done
Explain the operation to the best of your ability
Explain that you do not have enough knowledge of the procedure to discuss it
Suggest that he asks a nurse instead
Bleep your registrar to come and speak to the patient
Reflect on this incident in your ePortfolio
Suggest that he researches the procedure on the internet
Do some reading online then explain it to him
questions:
You are a surgical junior doctor on the vascular ward. Your team have just finished the morning ward round during which you saw a patient awaiting a complex procedure for arterial disease. He is booked in for theatre this afternoon. He calls you over after the team has left the ward to discuss concerns about the procedure. You have never seen this operation performed thus feel uncomfortable discussing it. What do you do?

Select the THREE most appropriate actions to take in this situation
notes:
The GMC Good Medical Practice (2013) states: 'You must be honest and trustworthy in all your communication with patients and colleagues. This means you must make clear the limits of your knowledge and make reasonable checks to make sure any information you give is accurate.' Hence you should explain to him that you do not have enough knowledge to discuss it. You can then solve the problem by bleeping your registrar who is better placed to explain the procedure to the patient. The only other appropriate answer is to reflect on the incident in your ePortfolio, because although this is obviously not a priority, the other answers are incorrect (see below).

It is not true that once a consent form has been signed there is nothing that can be done - a patient may withdraw from a procedure that they consented to even on the day. They also have the right to ask more questions after the consent form has been signed. If you do not feel comfortable providing correct information to a patient, you should not attempt to do this from memory. Although a nurse may know about an operation, they are not best placed to explain the risks and benefits and to address concerns, whereas your registrar (or consultant) would be. Although there is much information widely available on the internet, and many patients use it to find out information, the information online is not always correct. Suggesting that he looks it up online is therefore unwise because he may not get the information he needs.

title: Duty of candour
body:
All healthcare professionals must be honest when something has gone wrong. They must:
  • Tell the patient when something has gone wrong
  • Apologise to the patient (or carer or family member where appropriate)
  • Offer an appropriate resolution
  • Explain the potential short and long-term effects of the error

Important to note:
  • Saying sorry is not an admission of legal liability
  • The patient has a right to receive an apology from 'the most appropriate team member' - this will usually be the lead or accountable clinician
  • The process for reporting adverse incidents and near misses varies between different health organisations: you must follow your own organisations policy
  • The National Report d scheme
concept: You must know the limits of your knowledge, and make reasonable checks to ensure the information you give to patients is accurate

options: Contact the police
Question the child about why he came to hospital
Contact social services
Allow the child home following a plaster cast being applied and wait for the x-rays to be formally reported before taking any action
Ask the emergency department consultant for help in dealing with this situation
questions:
You are a ST1 doctor in the children's emergency department. A 6-year-old child is brought in by his father as he fell getting out of the car. When looking at his x-ray it looks as though the child has a twisting injury, however the x-ray has not been reported as yet. There are no alarming features to the fracture itself, and it could be managed with plaster casting. Furthermore, the x-ray reveals what looks like several old healed fractures, for which there are no notes to explain.

Rank in order the following actions in response to this situation
(1 = Most appropriate; 5 = Least appropriate)
notes:
The main themes in this scenario are child safety and recognising your level of competency.

From the scenario, it is clearly a possibility that this child is being physically abused by somebody. Therefore, the most appropriate actions in this scenario are those that act on this suspicion. However, recognising your level of competency is integral when dealing with a possible case of child abuse, which is why the most appropriate action is to ask a senior for help, in this case the emergency department consultant (option 5). Whenever there is a possibility of child abuse in one of your patients it is always wise to speak to a senior colleague, as they will have more experience in dealing with this than you will.

Questioning the child about what happened to him (option 2) is the next most appropriate selection. The child might disclose information that can help deal with this case.

Contacting social services (3) and the police (1) are both inappropriate actions. Social services are likely to be contacted, however this should not be the first thing that you do. Furthermore, it is unlikely that you will be the one who contacts social services as a ST1 doctor, as this will likely be left to somebody more senior. This is more appropriate than contacting the police, however, as the scenario does not require the police to be called.

The worst response to this scenario is to allow the child home following plaster casting and wait for the x-rays to be formally reported (option 4). You might well be wrong regarding the child, but if you are right yet do nothing then you are placing the child at risk of further abuse, more serious injury or possibly death. Any suspicions of child abuse should be brought to the attention of a senior without fail.

You are a junior doctor on a surgical placement. You are consenting several patients for different surgical procedures. When you begin to explain to a new patient what their surgery will involve, they stop you and state that the procedure being performed on them is incorrect.

Rank in order the following actions in response to this situation

notes:
GMC guidelines:


'You must treat patients fairly and with respect whatever their life choices and beliefs.'
'You must work in partnership with patients, sharing with them the information they will need to make decisions about their care'.

http://www.gmc-uk.org/guidance/goodmedicalpractice/partnerships.asp

  • You must take the patients views into account in every aspect of their healthcare. In this situation you need to explore their views and then double check using documented evidence before moving ahead with gaining consent. (3)

Confront the father with concerns regarding non accidental injury
Raise this matter with the most senior doctor / nurse in the department

questions:
You see a 6-year-old girl in minors in the emergency department. She presents with an angulated fracture to her humerus with a story about falling off a bed. The bruising over her arm to you looks old. On the attendance record, you notice that she has attended the emergency department 8 times in the last year with numerous injuries.

Choose the THREE most appropriate actions to take in this situation.
notes:
This question requires you to quickly risk assess and act in a safe and appropriate manner. This situation should cause concern regarding a non-accidental injury. In such a situation, you must always act to protect the child, so it will be appropriate to admit this child under the care of the paediatric team (option 4 and 5). This should be done with the support of your seniors in the department (option 3). Option 7 would be appropriate, but not the most pressing issue at hand. Option 6 is inappropriate, from a clinical perspective, a fractured humerus in a child should be seen by orthopaedics. In this situation, you would be looking to remove the child from the parents care so option 1 is inappropriate. Option 2 is likely to inflame the situation and should be avoided. At this point, it would not be your job to contact the police (option 8).

See http://www.gmc-uk.org/guidance/ethicalguidance/childrenguidance5663childprotection.asp for further guidelines.

options: Ask one of the female members of staff to hold her down whilst you take blood
Put her on the observation ward

questions:
You are a F2 doctor working in the Emergency Department. A 19-year-old female is admitted with abdominal pain. Her observations are stable and she seems to have 'voluntary' guarding on examination of her abdomen. She refuses to have blood saying she has a phobia of needles.

Rank in order the following actions in response to this situation
(1 = Most appropriate; 5 = Least appropriate)
notes:
This scenario looks at whether you can adopt a sympathetic approach when dealing with patients.

As a first step it is important to discuss why you want to perform blood tests.

As the patient does not seem to be seriously ill it is acceptable to wait 30 minutes for the EMLA cream to work before taking bloods. Changing your usual management by not performing bloods is not good practice. Refusing treatment for any reason is not a reason to discharge a patient. Holding the patient down in such a situation would constitute assault.

questions:
You are a junior doctor working in general practice. You have just finished your morning surgery. One of the reception staff calls to ask if you would speak to a man who is causing an issue in the waiting area. You have previously seen him and know he is a former intravenous drug user. He is getting angry and demanding you issue him a one week supply of Subutex (buprenorphine) as he has 'family court next week'. He usually collects this daily from the pharmacy. What do you do?

Rank in order the following actions in response to this situation (A=Most appropriate; E= Least appropriate)
notes:
The best way to deal with angry or distressed patients is, as always, to try to diffuse the situation by taking them to a quiet place and having a discussion in private. You should remain calm, listen to what they are saying and provide them with an opportunity to explain what has angered them. You can find out exactly what the issue is and try to come to a solution together with the patient.

However, this request is complicated by the fact that the patient is demanding you give him a medication which is usually collected daily as it has the potential to be abused and giving him a weeks supply could be very dangerous particularly if he gives it to others and this must be considered. In difficult situations such as this it is reasonable to involve your seniors early for support and guidance.

You should refuse to give him a week's supply (option C) but you may be able to come to a compromise, e.g. to collect it at a pharmacy closer to the court. Although asking him to leave may seem a bit extreme it is better than giving him the medication.

title: Patient complaints
body:
It is important to be open and respond appropriately when a patient makes a complaint. This may happen through a number of channels:
  • verbal complaint
  • informal or formal written complaint addressed to the doctor concerned
  • complaint addressed to a managing body e.g. hospital trust or GP practice
  • complaint to the GMC

It should of course be remembered that patient complaints or comments may be unwarranted or without basis and therefore a formal reply is usually required to ensure the doctor has given their account of what has happened.

options: Confront the family members about the situation to ensure they're aware of the privacy breach
Document the incident and report it to your practice manager for further investigation
Ignore the situation assuming it's a personal matter and not your responsibility
Share the incident with other staff members to raise awareness about the importance of patient confidentiality
Speak to the staff member privately, explaining the breach of trust and the importance of respecting others' confidentiality
questions:
You are working in general practice. You discover that a member of staff has been accessing the medical records of their family members without their knowledge.

Rank in order the appropriateness of the following actions in response to this situation (1= Most appropriate; 5= Least appropriate).
notes:
Speaking privately with the staff member (E) is a crucial first step in addressing the breach of patient confidentiality. This action allows you to address the issue discreetly and professionally. By explaining the breach of trust and emphasising the importance of patient confidentiality, you provide an opportunity for the staff member to understand the gravity of their actions and make amends while protecting patients' privacy.

Reporting the breach (B) to the practice manager is the next appropriate step, as it ensures that the matter is escalated for a thorough investigation. This action helps uphold patient confidentiality and ensures accountability within the practice.

While there is a duty of candour to inform patients if their confidentiality has been breached, immediate confrontation with the family members (A) may not be the best initial approach. It's important first to address the staff member's behaviour and take steps to prevent further breaches. Once the situation is under control, informing the affected family members can be considered in a more measured and sensitive manner.

While raising awareness about patient confidentiality is important, sharing the specific incident with other staff members (D) might not be the first course of action. It's advisable to address the issue privately with the staff member and escalate it through official channels (such as reporting to the practice manager) before considering broader awareness efforts.

Ignoring the situation (C) is not a responsible or ethical approach. Patient confidentiality is a fundamental principle in healthcare, and breaches must be addressed promptly. Failing to take action in this scenario would disregard the well-being and privacy of patients whose records were accessed improperly.

title: GMC: Confidentiality - Disclosing patients personal information: a framework
body:
Confidentiality is an important ethical and legal duty but it is not absolute. Doctors may disclose personal information without breaching duties of confidentiality when any of the following circumstances apply:
  • The patient consents, whether implicitly or explicitly
    • for the sake of their own care
    • for local clinical audit
    • explicitly for other purposes
  • The patient has given their explicit consent to disclosure for other purposes
  • The disclosure is of overall benefit to a patient who lacks the capacity to consent
  • The disclosure is required by law
  • The disclosure can be justified in the public interest
    • e.g. serious communicable diseases or serious crime

When disclosing information about a patient you must:
  • use anonymised information if possible and if it will serve the purpose be satisfied the patient:
    • has ready access to information explaining how their personal information will be used for their own care or local clinical audit, and that they have the right to object
    • has not objected
  • get the patient's explicit consent if identifiable information is to be disclosed for purposes other than their own care or local clinical audit, unless the disclosure is required by law or can be justified in the public interest
  • keep disclosures to the minimum necessary for the purpose
  • follow all relevant legal requirements, including the common law and data protection law

You should tell patients about disclosures you make that they would not reasonably expect, or check they have received information about such disclosures, unless that is not practicable or would undermine the purpose of the disclosure - for example, by prejudicing the prevention, detection or prosecution of serious crime
